I.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE FACILITY 
A.     Justification 
 
1.  The portfolio of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) in the People’s Republic of China 
(PRC) has been realigned to multisector projects and moved to municipal and county levels, to 
tackle the rural, environmental, and regional development challenges in the PRC. Such projects 
are highly complex and challenging to realize, and their success hinges on the capacity of the 
executing  and  implementing  agencies.  During  the  2017  country  program  mission,  the 
Government of the PRC requested ADB to provide technical assistance (TA) to build the capacity 
of the executing and implementing agencies in the PRC for better project implementation. ADB 
included the proposed transaction TA facility in the country operations business plan, 2018–2020 
for the PRC.1  
 
2.  As of 31 December 2017, ADB’s portfolio in the PRC had 91 active loan projects for a net 
amount of $12.7 billion. The performance of the portfolio has been declining, although it is still far 
above ADB average.2 More projects encountered implementation delays. About 41.7% of them 
required extensions, and the average period of extension increased from 1 year to 2.1 years in 
2017. The average age of the projects based on the year of loan effectiveness increased steadily 
from 3.2 in 2013 to 3.8 in 2017. In 2017, 36 loans had implementation period of 6 or more years—
12 loans of 6 years, 14 of 7 years, 7 of 8 years, and 3 of 9 years. Changes in project scope 
became frequent. In 2017 alone, 47 minor changes were made to PRC projects. In addition, the 
number of projects with an actual problem rating increased.3 The complexity of the projects and 
the weak capacity of executing and implementing agency staff at municipal and township levels 
contributed the most to these problems. 
 
3.  From 2010 to 2017, the proportion of multisector projects in the PRC portfolio increased 
dramatically, from about 15% to about 50%. Moreover, the projects that intended to address 
environmental challenges and urban development issues increased to 56% of the portfolio in the 
PRC. To implement these projects, multilevel government administration and multiple project 
implementation units are involved. A large proportion of the executing and implementing agencies 
are  at  municipal  and  county  level,  or  even  at  township  level.  Their  staff  shoulder  key 
responsibilities  in  project  implementation  but  have  little  or  no  experience  in  working  with 
international financial institutions. They need to be equipped with knowledge and skills for project 
management; familiarized with ADB’s policies, guidelines, and procedures; and enabled to find 
practical solutions to specific operational issues. 
 
4.  Since 1987 when ADB began operations in the country, ADB and the Government of the 
PRC have made various efforts to boost the executing and implementing agencies’ capacity 
across different areas of a project cycle. These efforts were successful in giving the agencies the 
tools  to  prepare  and  implement  projects  funded  by  ADB  and  other  international  financial 
institutions. However, now that ADB’s portfolio in the PRC has evolved and project administration 
moves to counties and townships, fresh demand for capacity building arises. Most of the new 
executing and implementing agencies comes across an externally funded project for the first time. 
ADB’s requirements, guidelines, and practices are totally new to them. It is imperative to introduce 
them  to  ADB’s  guidelines  and  procedures.  Staff  at  these  agencies  also  need  broad  and 
fundamental knowledge and skills to manage different project implementation aspects, such as

project management and contract management. Moreover, to be able to handle day-to-day 
implementation issues in a timely manner, they need to find practical solutions and good practices 
in the county context.  
 
5.  In addition, the training efficiency and effectiveness could be further improved. It is 
important to deliver the right knowledge and skills to the right person at the right time. Within the 
same topic, different roles in project implementation require different levels of training. Within the 
same  role,  staff  will  need  different  depths  of  knowledge  at  different  stages  of  project 
implementation. Taking procurement as an example, it may be enough for the director of a project 
management office to understand the general principles and the differences between ADB and 
government practices, whereas a procurement officer needs to know every aspect of procurement 
in detail and requires more training than a generic session on procurement guidelines. To tackle 
complex procurement issues, the procurement officer also needs practical training on  issues 
encountered in daily tasks. 
 
6.  The proposed TA facility will help the government develop the capacity of executing and 
implementing  agencies  for  managing  ADB-financed  projects  in  the  PRC.  It  builds  on  the 
successful  implementation  of  a  previous  capacity-building  TA.4 That TA  contributed to the 
analysis  of  training  needs  and  the  development  of  a  comprehensive  training  program  for 
executing and implementing agencies. The analysis showed that the demand for training by 
county and township staff is overwhelming and that the training topics requested go far beyond 
the scope of current courses available at ADB. These training needs cover project management; 
procurement; contract management; financial management; ADB’s safeguards (resettlement, 
environment,  indigenous  peoples);  disbursement; monitoring  of gender targets;  and  project 
performance evaluation. For each topic, different levels of detail were requested, and in addition 
to the theoretical knowledge, staff also requested practical experience in almost all topics. 
 
7.  The comprehensive training program consists of 20 courses grouped into 6 categories 
that are tailored to different positions within a project management office. 5 Of the 20 training 
courses, 9 shall be newly developed covering project management, contract management, project 
performance  evaluation,  and  hands-on  training  on  procurement,  financial  management, 
safeguards, and disbursement. In 2017, the earlier TA (footnote 4) developed a training course 
on project management for the directors of project management offices. The proposed TA facility 
will support the development of the remaining eight training courses with the assistance of 
consultants and guided by ADB specialists. The new training courses will mainly focus on hands-
on experience and practical solutions for each topic. 
 
8.  The training program for the executing and implementing agencies will be implemented 
systematically,  i.e.,  training  will  be  targeted  at  staff  according  to  their  roles  in  project 
implementation and the specific implementation stage of their projects. The TA facility will cover 
cross-sharing of operational experiences between the executing and implementing agencies as 
it is another effective way of obtaining practical knowledge. The TA facility will provide project 
implementation support to the executing and implementing agencies of all ongoing projects in the 
PRC, and it will be expanded to new executing and implementing agencies of new projects to be 
committed in 2018 and thereafter.

5 The six categories comprise procurement, financial management and disbursement, safeguard policies, project 
management, project monitoring and evaluation, and other topics (such as cutting-edge technical knowledge). On 
each subject, general and/or advanced as well as hands-on training courses are proposed to meet the executing and 
implementing agencies’ needs.

3 
B.  Outputs and Activities 
 
9.  The TA facility is to enhance the capacity of the executing and implementing agencies in 
the PRC for better project implementation through targeted, practical, and systematic training 
courses and knowledge-sharing activities. The outputs are (i) development of tailor-made training 
courses  on  procurement,  financial  management,  safeguards,  disbursement,  contract 
management,  and  project  performance  evaluation;  (ii)  training  workshops,  which  will  be 
systematically provided to staff of the executing and implementing agencies, based on the staff’s 
role in project implementation and the implementation stage of their projects; and (iii) knowledge-
sharing activities, to share knowledge and experiences in various areas of project management 
among the executing and implementing agencies in the PRC. 
 
10.  Output  1:  Development  of  tailor-made  training  courses.  The  hands-on  training 
courses  on  procurement,  financial  management,  safeguards,  disbursement,  Fédération 
lnternationale  Des  lngénieurs  Conseils  (FIDIC)  and  contract  management,  and  project 
performance evaluation will be developed with the assistance of consultants. The training will 
focus on the common issues encountered by the executing and implementing agencies in the 
PRC during project implementation in the respective area. Developing these courses requires the 
joint efforts of ADB specialists and consultants who have practical experience in the respective 
areas of project implementation. 
 
11.  Output 2: Training workshops. Systematic training will be provided to the staff of 
executing  and  implementing  agencies  on  procurement,  financial  management,  safeguards, 
disbursement, as well as project management, contract management, and project performance 
evaluation. The targeted staff will be invited to participate in the training course(s) based on their 
roles in project implementation. In general, two training workshops on procurement, project 
management, and FIDIC and contract management and one training workshop on financial 
management, safeguards, disbursement, and project performance evaluation will be carried out 
every year. In total, it is planned to conduct about twenty training workshops under this output. 
 
12.  Output 3: Knowledge-sharing activities. Knowledge sharing among the executing and 
implementing agencies in the PRC will be promoted through thematic workshops, country portfolio 
review missions, best practice sharing, and provincial visits, among other avenues. By the end of 
2017, ADB had financed 248 loans in the PRC, of which 91 are ongoing. Abundant experiences 
and lessons in implementing ADB-financed projects in the PRC have accumulated in the years of 
ADB’s engagement with the PRC. Under the TA facility, the good experiences and practices will 
be abstracted and shared with the executing and implementing agencies of ongoing projects. At 
least five knowledge-sharing events will be carried out under the TA facility. In addition, the TA 
facility will also cover the cost of resource persons as needed, such as technical expertise for 
introducing new technologies.        
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
13.  The TA facility is estimated to cost $1,400,000, of which $700,000 will be financed on a 
grant  basis  by  ADB’s  Technical  Assistance  Special  Fund  (TASF-other  sources).  The  cost 
estimates, financing plan, and key expenditure items are listed in Appendix 1. The government 
will provide counterpart support in the form of office space for consultation meetings, domestic 
transportation for all participants, shared accommodation when appropriate, and other in-kind 
contributions.

4 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
14.  ADB will administer the TA facility working closely with the PRC counterparts. The East 
Asia Department’s PRC Resident Mission will lead the implementation of the TA facility in close 
coordination with the Office of the Director General and relevant sector divisions of the East Asia 
Department, and other departments of ADB as necessary. This includes selecting, administering, 
and  supervising  the  consultants,  developing  training  materials,  and  conducting  training 
workshops and knowledge-sharing events. The implementation arrangements are summarized in 
Table 1.

15.  Consulting services. ADB will engage the consultants following its Procurement Policy 
(2017, as amended from time to time) and its associated project administration instructions and/or 
staff instructions.6 Consultants will be selected using the individual consultant selection method, 
and lump-sum or output-based contracts will be considered for their services. The single-source 
selection method will be used to engage the trainers involved in the previous capacity-building TA 
(footnote 4) to continue the training initiated, as well as consultants from specialized agencies 
such as Fédération lnternationale Des lngénieurs Conseils and resource persons needed to 
introduce new technologies. 
 
II.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
16.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $700,000 on a grant basis to the 
Government of the People’s Republic of China for Enhancing the Capacity of Executing and 
Implementing Agencies for Better Project Implementation, and hereby reports this action to the 
Board.
